evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing. After the collision, she suggested not moving the aircraft off the blast fence.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25 in the hist_t3_prefinal phase.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: There is no evidence contradicting the presence of communication/coordination breakdown among crew in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal phase, indicating strong defeater resistance for this root cause.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features of coordination failures such as miscommunication, lack of clarity, and delayed information sharing in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal context.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25 in the hist_t3_prefinal phase.

defeaters: If evidence showed clear, timely communication and coordination preventing or addressing the overrun
If crew members had actively warned or corrected each other during the event

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence (H8, H10, H12) directly indicates a lack of effective communication and coordination among the crew during the pushback, as no warnings were given or questioned despite the aircraft passing the TRP and hitting the blast fence.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in the extent of communication attempts and possible unrecorded verbal exchanges

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features of coordination failures such as miscommunication, lack of clarity, and delayed information sharing in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal context.

assumptions: Assuming that lack of warnings and assumptions by crew indicate miscommunication and lack of clarity
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, timely communication and warnings were given and acknowledged among crew
If the crew had explicit protocols that were followed preventing miscommunication

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
The trainee driver ... did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 directly describe miscommunication, lack of clarity, and delayed or absent information sharing among crew during the pushback, consistent with coordination failure features.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit mention of all communication exchanges; some assumptions about intent and awareness of crew members.

slot_statements.availability: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and identifiable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection phase on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against potential defeaters, maintaining validity and reliability within the context of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_t3_prefinal inspection.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The environmental or marking deficiency should correspond to the key features defined for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the hist_t3_prefinal inspection, ensuring it matches expected patterns or criteria.

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and identifiable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection phase on 12-25.

defeaters: If evidence showed a missing or unclear Tug Release Point (TRP) marking or other environmental/marking deficiencies at the time and location specified.
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence indicates the presence or identification of an environmental or marking deficiency on the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection phase on 12-25.

slot_statements.availability: Mechanical/control failure was present and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal phase on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: Mechanical/control failure withstands potential defeaters and remains a valid explanation for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal phase on 12-25.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: Mechanical/control failure aligns with the key features identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal phase on 12-25.

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure was present and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal phase on 12-25.

defeaters: Evidence of mechanical or control failure during the specified phase would change my mind.
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence indicates any mechanical or control failure was present or observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal phase on 12-25; all evidence describes tug driver actions and pushback events without mention of mechanical/control failure (H1-H13).

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and available in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical timeline prefinal records.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of procedural deviation in pushback execution withstands potential counterarguments and alternative explanations within the context of Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical timeline prefinal data.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with the key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 pushback operations during the historical timeline prefinal phase.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and available in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical timeline prefinal records.

defeaters: If no formal documentation or record of the deviation existed in the historical timeline
If the records were incomplete or inaccessible

outcome.reasoning_summary: The historical records (H1-H13) document the procedural deviation during pushback, including the sequence of events, personnel involved, and the aircraft passing the TRP and hitting the blast barrier, confirming the deviation is documented and available in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical timeline prefinal records.
outcome.uncertainty_source: None significant; the evidence directly documents the event in the specified historical timeline
